column4: An ontology related to the "Body" could be structured as follows:1. Body: The physical structure of a being, which includes all its physiological systems, and is fundamental for its life and functioning.    1.1. Human body: A complex structure possessed by humans.        1.1.1. Cardiovascular system: The system that circulates blood around the body through the heart, veins, and arteries.        1.1.2. Digestive system: The system responsible for breaking down food into nutrients.        1.1.3. Musculoskeletal system: The system that provides the human body with physical stability and the ability to move.        1.1.4. Nervous system: The network of nerve cells and fibers which transmits nerve impulses between parts of the body.        1.1.5. Skin: The outer covering of the body.        1.1.6. Reproductive system: The system of organs involved in producing offspring.    1.2. Animal body: Bodies of non-human animals, including mammals, reptiles, fish, birds, and insects.        1.2.1. Exoskeleton: A rigid external covering for the body in some invertebrate animals.        1.2.2. Wings: Limbs adapted for flying or gliding.        1.2.3. Fins: An external appendage or outgrowth on a fish, used for propulsion and steering.        1.2.4. Fur: The hair covering the bodies of many animals.        1.2.5. Scales: Hard, thin plates that cover the skin of many fish and reptiles.    1.3. Plant body: The physical structure of a plant, including roots, stem, leaves, and flowers.        1.3.1. Roots: Part of the plant that typically lies below the surface of the soil.            1.3.2. Stem: The main structural part of a plant.        1.3.3. Leaves: The main organ of photosynthesis and transpiration in plants.        1.3.4. Flowers: The seed-bearing part of a plant, consisting of reproductive organs.        1.3.5. Fruits: The mature ovary of a flowering plant, typically containing seeds.2. Body Parts: The different distinct pieces that make up the body.    2.1. Head: The uppermost part of the human body, containing the brain and the eyes, ears, nose, mouth, and jaws.        2.2. Arms: The two upper limbs of the human body, used for grasping and holding.        2.3. Legs: The two lower limbs of the human body, used for walking and standing.        2.4. Torso: The trunk of the human body.        2.5. Hands and Feet: The extremities of the arms and legs, used for manipulation and locomotion respectively.3. Body Functions: The physiological processes that the body carries out to maintain homeostasis.    3.1. Respiration: The process by which the body takes in oxygen and expels carbon dioxide.        3.2. Digestion: The process by which the body breaks down food into nutrients.        3.3. Circulation: The process by which the heart pumps blood throughout the body.        3.4. Sensation: The process by which the body perceives and responds to its environment.        3.5. Reproduction: The process by which the body creates new individuals.4. Body States: The physical and physiological conditions that the body can be in.    4.1. Health: The state of being free from illness or injury.        4.2. Disease: A condition of the body, or of some part or organ of the body, in which its functions are disrupted or deranged.        4.3. Growth: The process of increasing in size.        4.4. Aging: The process of becoming older.        4.5. Death: The ending of all biological functions that sustain a living organism.
